name: fundamental elements of everything that exists
author: Michel Moreau
post: A finite set of non-identical entities, their motion, and the relations between the finite set of entities with motion state.

name: Life inputs that can change
author: Michel Moreau
post:
Relations

  • The time spent with specific individuals.
  • The way one behaves with specific individuals.
  • The willingness to be authentic with other individuals.
  • The willingess to understand other individuals.

Environment

  • The air one breathes.
  • The sun exposition.
  • The light exposition.
  • The physical spaces one spends time in.
  • The sounds exposition.
  • The objects one interacts with.
  • The objects one is in contact with.

Movement

  • The amount.
  • The intensity.
  • The type.

Dietetics

  • Drugs.
  • Food.
  • Water.
  • Air.
  • Skin absorption.

Sleep

  • The amount.
  • The routine pre-sleep.
  • The routine post-sleep.

Knowledge

  • The type.
  • The quantity.

Experiences

  • The type.
  • The quantity.
  • The intensity.

Cognitions

  • Habitual thoughts.
  • Non-habitual thoughts.
  • Self-limiting thoughts.
  • Self-empowering thoughts.
  • External-world-limiting thoughts.
  • External-world-empowering thoughts.
Everything that can change can change.

name: ten guidelines for maintainable code from Joost Visser et alia
author: Michel Moreau
post:
Write short units of code.

Write simple units of code.

Write code once.

Keep unit interfaces small.

Seperate concerns in module.

Couple components architecture loosely.

Keep component architecture balanced.

Keep your codebase small.

Automate tests.

Write clean code.

These rules were taken from the excellent book Building Maintainable Software: Ten Guidelines for Future-Proof Code

name: the only real and timeless definition of success
author: Michel Moreau
post: Alignment and harmony between what you think, say, do, and feel.

name: On life pivoting
author: Michel Moreau
post:
You want to switch career, start a business or get a promotion.

You want to lose weight, sleep longer, stop smoking or gain muscles.

You want to breakup, find a life partner, meet more girls or like-minded guys.

You want to buy a nice house, a dream car, a shiny watch or head-turning outfits.

You want to be less materialistic, live simply or be contempt with what you have.

You want to feel happier, complete, successful or more connected to meaningful others.

You want to be sociable, emotionally intelligent, less needy or more balanced.

You want to be able to have difficult conversations, display honesty toward yourself and others in all situations.

You want. Wanting invites either stagnation or unhabitual change.

Stagnation implies pain.

Unhabitual change implies pain.

Stagnation implies an unconscious, visceral, long-lasting, deferred, potentially explosive pain leading to the absolute certainty of an unfulfilled want.

Unhabitual change implies a conscious, acute, ephemeral, likely mind-expanding pain leading to the potential fulfillment of your want.

Being conscious of these two types of pains and their outcomes makes the choice between stagnation and unhabitual change obvious.

Through courage to endure pain of unhabitual change, living your best life becomes more likely.
